instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (no Back Light) No Liquid Damage.

0 Volts on J9000 (Pins 3,4)
0 Volts on <CAPACITOR>C9713</CAPACITOR>
0 Volts on <RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR>

<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>
8.4V on Pin (4) 7.9 on Pin (3)
0 Volts on 1,2,5,6

any help is greatly appreciated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
threads.message:
You didn't tell us if it has image...
USB mouse works at least?
Do you get voltage at pins 18/19 of J9000?
Also check <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
threads.message:
replaced Screen at the beginning which was a waste of time. should've checked the Voltage first.

MBA fully functional on external display.
Yes there is DATA (Dark Image)

Fuse> assuming you are talking about F9700 (8.4V Both sides)

i'll check J9000 (P18/19)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
threads.message:
If you get image means display is correctly recognized, so there is voltage; no need to check it.
Check above mentioned signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
threads.message: No way both of them are low or the system wouldn't even boot. Check them with an LCD connected of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No LCDBKLT
threads.message: Board was picked by customer (He says the Genius Bar told him they would look at it) loool, made me laugh i packed his laptop in a heartbeat. we'll see when he comes back.,
